history.content:
Are you interested in learning about security or databases? I took both classes and enjoyed both immensely! 

I definitely saw content learned in both classes applied in industry during my internships. I wouldn’t say one of the classes are significantly “harder” than the other, and really comes down to what you’re interested in. Both have high workload at times when projects are released, and very low workload when you’re waiting on the next project to be released. 

You can take a look at the material from previous semesters on each class’ website and see what you would like more to help your decision.

In terms of grading, 186 is probably the nicest CS class at Berkeley.

I definitely saw content learned in both classes applied in industry during my internships. I wouldn’t say one of the classes are significantly “harder” than the other, and really comes down to what you’re interested in. children.subject: I would say 161 has applications in almost any software role you might take, while 186 might not be as useful if you aren't planning to work with databases :)
Everything else aside, I found 161 more fun and in a world where I could strictly take only 1 of the 2, I would take 161 every time. However, I recommend taking both if you have the time.

As a plus for 186, the concepts and ideas you learn in 186 can help you think about general system design with large amounts of data, not just strictly databases. Ideas on concurrency and parallelism and thinking about how best to split data across multiple machines and recombine in databases is related to things you may have to do in cloud computing, distributed systems. Mainly saying this because I had some interviews that involved these kind of problems, and 186 knowledge came in real handy for thinking about/iterating on designs that involve these ideas. 

(That said, 161 is probably more immediately useful to SWE and I thought it was more fun.)

history.content: If I could only take one of those classes, what would make me want to take one class over the other? Is the content of one class significantly harder to learn than the other?
history.subject: 161 vs 186 learning outcomes
